newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: HOCKEY-GERMANY END DUTCH WINNING STREAK.
newsitem.headline: HOCKEY-GERMANY END DUTCH WINNING STREAK.

text.p: Germany ended a 25-match unbeaten streak by the Netherlands when they won their final pool match at the five-nation Golden Jubilee of Pakistan men's tournament on Saturday.
The Germans, who face the Netherlands again in the tournament final on Sunday, came from behind to win the dead pool game 3-1.
It was the first time the Dutch had lost an international since June of last year, before their Olympic triumph in Atlanta.

But Dutch coach Roelant Oltmans was not worried about the defeat. "There is always one match you are going to lose. It would not be good for us to worry about defending an unbeaten run," he said. "I used the match for team development."
The result left Germany top of the round robin series, three points ahead of the Netherlands.
Netherlands were without Erik Jazet, who was called home for personal reasons, and did not play their captain Stephan Veen in the second half.
Bram Lomans, the Dutch corner specialist who, for a change, had a long outing on the field, put the Dutch ahead from their third corner of the match in the 29th minute.
German under-21 striker Oliver Domke scored a spectacular equaliser with a reverse hit in the 49th minute.
Christian Blunck, the German captain, raced forward to hit a loose ball into goal for Germany's second goal and Domke set up Christian Bechmann for the third.
Australia who play World Cup holders Pakistan for bronze on Sunday, drew 3-3 with them in their final round robin match.

Australia led three times through Matthew Smith, Jeremy Hiskins and Stephen Davies and missed a chance to go ahead again when a 57th-minute penalty by Davies was saved by Pakistan captain Mansoor Ahmed.
Pakistan's scorers were Rahim Khan, Muhammad Khalid junior and Muhammad Shahbaz.
